div.p: From the Secretary, Ballarat Benevolent Asylum Committee

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Letter not found. For the text given here, see Ballarat star, 19 June 1862, p. 1 S, under the heading ‘Planting the reserve’. The news item reports the meeting of the committee held on 16 June 1862.

p.seg: [The Secretary read a report from Mr G. Smith (under whose gratuitous superintendence the grounds are being planted), acknowledging the receipt from the Botanic Gardens, Melbourne, of a parcel of ornamental trees and shrubs, comprising several varieties of cypress, pine, cedar, &c, also a parcel of bulbs, which he considered worth about £36.
The report was received and it was resolved- "That the secretary convey the thanks of the committee to Dr
for the trees and shrubs forwarded for the Institution from the Melbourne Botanic Garden"].
